translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)
The Chapter of the Cuckoo
The Dabbha Flower Birth Story
“I’m not crossing, good sir,
but follow my friend.
I’ve caught a big fish,
and it’s dragging me away.”
“I’m crossing deep, good sir,
grab hold firmly and with strength.
I’ll pull you out,
like a supaṇṇa a snake.”
“A dispute has arisen between us,
Dabbha Flower, listen to me.
Let’s settle this, you clever one,
and let the dispute be resolved.”
“In the past I was firm in the Teaching,
and many were the ones I helped.
Let’s settle this, you clever one,
and let the dispute be resolved.
The tail belongs to the one who doesn’t cross,
and the head to the one who crosses deep.
The middle section, which is the most valuable,

analyzed: dhammaṭṭhassa bhavissati  ciram pi bhakkho abhavissa
translated: will belong to the one who is firm in the Teaching.”🔽“If we hadn’t argued,
the food would have lasted a long time.
Without tail or head,

analyzed: siṅgālaḥ harati rohita  yathā api rājā nandeyya
translated: the jackal is carrying off the Rohita.”🔽“Just as a king or a noble
would rejoice on receiving a kingdom,
so I rejoice today,
and saw her husband with a full face.
How is it that you, who are a land animal,
can fondle a fish in the water?
When asked, good sir, tell me,
how did you come to know this?”
“Through quarreling one becomes thin,
through quarreling one’s wealth is lost;
The defeated are carried off,
enjoy the crafty Rohita.
In the same way, among humans,
wherever quarreling arises;
They run to the one who is righteous,
for he is their leader.
There wealth is lost,
and the royal treasury increases.”
The Dabbha Flower Jātaka, the fifth.
